title: How to Host a Capture the Flag Birthday Party

steps.headline: Plan for the weather.
steps.description: Heavy rain or harsh sunshine can quickly put the dampeners on any party. Look at the weather forecast, and plan the party on a pleasant day. Cloudy days work best, as they clouds can block out the sun to ensure the play area stays nice and cool.

steps.headline: Invite many people .
steps.description: Capture the flag is a lot more fun when you have a large amount of people playing. Make sure you have a big enough attendance at the party to keep things interesting.

steps.headline: Know the rules.
steps.description: Set the rules well in advance to avoid any conflicts or disputes later on. To do this, you'll need to know how capture the flag is played, and then make all your guests aware of exactly how the game is played. There are many variations of capture the flag, so even if your guests know how to play, it's still important to tell the them the rules so they know which variation of the game they'll be playing. Tip: For added excitement, try experimenting with your own house rules! This will take your guests by surprise, and will be more fun for everyone.}

steps.headline: Be ready to resolve conflicts.
steps.description: Capture the flag is notorious for causing arguments. It can be hard to tell who was over line, who tagged who, or who was cheating. Have a method for breaking up arguments before the party ends in an all out tear-fest. You can ask one of your guests to referee, or you could do it yourself.

steps.headline: Bake or buy a cake.
steps.description: Your guests probably aren't going to want to run around the whole time. They'll happily pause for a cake break. Essential to any good party, cakes and beverages can be a good way to break up a really long and tiring game, or mark the end of a  short one. They'll help your hungry guests unwind and relax.

steps.headline: Plan other activities.
steps.description: While Capture the Flag is going to be the main event, it's a good idea to plan some other lighter activities for guests who are unable to play, or simply if you want to keep the game relatively short but extend the duration of the party. Either way, a bit of variety can go a long way in making the party memorable.

steps.headline: Prepare the flag.
steps.description: Flags are the most important bit of any game. These will be grabbed and handled quite roughly, so make sure to get something made out of high quality materials. Poor quality flags may rip and tear halfway through the game, and can be quite the party pooper. Tip: If you want to save money on the flag, try using towels. Towels are sturdy and durable, and can be washed after use.}

steps.headline: Set up the jail.
steps.description: You're going to need something to mark boundaries and safe zones and the jail. Cones or a long rope tend to work well for marking the boundaries between the two sides. Hula hoops or a rope circle are good for the jail circle, as well as the flag circle. You can use anything really, but try to make the boundaries clear.

steps.headline: Gather team colors.
steps.description: These aren't really necessary, but can help tell who's on which team. You could buy some sort of marker, like caps or bandanas, to help with this. Alternatively, you could form the teams in advance and ask your guests to wear their team colors.
